comments.commentBody: Funeral Home:  EnCrypted
I really hope there's a music store in the Village with: MyBiGuyHiFiWiFi
I am an atheist.  I don't get it.  Any of it.  It all seems so silly.

What a pathetic collection of straw men, tu quoque's, non-sequiturs, irrelevant references to ancient history, and labeling everybody who you disagree with "Republican". Meanwhile, instead of guessing what Awlaki WOULD say, why not open eyes and see what Hamas HAS said, welcoming this project? Hey, let's build it right where the towers stood - it would be a much stronger "force for moderation".

"Setting aside the "likes and don't likes" of the issue, has anyone checked the source of the financing the mosque?"#256
Oh no, what a horrible idea. The correct party line is : Islam is wonderful, Islam's history is wonderful, all Muslims are wonderful,etc." Don't you think that checking can be offensive to the wonderful.
I think you are thinking and this is bad. Can I give you an advice: check what the Republicans say and reverse. If they are critical, you praise immediately. Simple. And easy. And you can spend your happy days on the beach.

I applaud Mr. Kristof's thoughtful column.  Does anyone objecting know or care who these particular muslims are?  Is what happened on 9/11 to be an eternal memorial of us against them?  There is still a lot of anger sorrow and hatred out there....that needs to be addressed somehow....banning a mosque or a hundred mosques is not going to assuage it.

basically, mr. kristoff is his usual idiot self.  i indeed am islamophobic-every time i get on a plane with muslim-looking young punks, i hold my breath until the plane lands. we should deport them all.
The turbid thinking of the right wing nut jobs show themselves to be the taliban in our republic.

I feel as if I have been jettisoned into some alternative universe. How can it be that in America, in New York, among educated people, that so much emotion and so many words are being flung at a non-issue?

Even as a self-professed hater of most, if not all organized religions, I cannot find one iota of grounds on which to base any attempt to deny citizens the right to build a religious community center and mosque wherever the hell they please.

I beg you all, let us please address the many very real problems facing us both here and in the larger world. As a secular Jew, these arguments based on religious positions are starting to scare me.

as a muslim american,  I am tired of this debate on that community center-mosque issue. In Islam, you dont have to go to a specific place -except friday pray- to pray.So I dont know why   its  so imperative to bulid a mosque in a place which makes so many others bothered!!! secondly, islam is not 30 years old religion.Its very unfair to bind islam with violence cause some referenced their murder with it.There are 1.5 billion believers of Islam and most of these people never ever justify any violence against christians or jews or any human beings.

"Thank you for your defense of humanity. I am already deeply ashamed"#202
Oh, Abby, our historical expert. Now, when you already know that White Russians were not exactly socialists (even thought a Hollywood film somehow made you believe so), you can move to a new topic. Bravo, Abby, bravo.

Islam is a religion that instructs its adherents to strive for a world totalitarian state - a Caliphate - in which Sharia Law will be the supreme law of the land.  It demands that all other religions be subordinate to and pay tribute Islam, or be destroyed.  As such, it is inimical to the Constitution of the USA.  The Ground Zero mosque is a victory monument to the "martyrs" who flew the planes into the World Trade Center Towers.  Islam is as much a religion as Communism and Fascism, and should be accorded the same treatment by the USA
Your article on the Islam controversy is excellent and shows clear thinking among all the emotional reactions taking .place.   Irving

Some points in perspective of this column:
1) Bible is the sacred book for Muslims and Christ ( may peace be upon Him) is as respectful as others holy Messengers. According to Islam all heavenly Religions carry the same message, ultimate peace and prosperity at the face of earth.
2) Again I think true and real teachings of Bible can not promote violence as it depicts severely in crusade wars and recently in current wars.
3) Narrow interest based policies, two wars in Muslim countries, supporting of dictators in Muslim countries of course created such wide spread point of views in Muslim world that created further gulf.
At the end thank you.

The comments about your column (and all others on this topic) reveal a lot about our country.

We are weak, and base, and as manipulatable as any other peoples. We will not live up to our constitution, to our principals, and to our morals. When push comes to shove, it will be us against them, we will again deny people their rights based on nothing more than race or religion.

Not even 100 years ago, we denied Americans their civil rights. Not just African Americans, not just Japanese Americans, but Indians in America from India, Chinese Americans before WWII were denied their rights in this nation. They did not have the right to citizenship or land ownership, or the right to intermarriage -- antimiscegenation laws applied to all asian groups). Read Ron Takaki on this.

In these last nine years we have broken every principal we had, out of fear and cowardice. I understand why we did this, but I thought we were bigger than this, better than this.

Out of fear, we have accepted the torturing of innocent Muslim men in Iraq, in Afghanistan, and when it has been inconvenient for us to torture our prisoners, we have sent them to our allies, Egypt or Morrocco or where ever, for torture. After all, they are just Moslem savages. They are wife beaters, primitive men living in caves, stoning people for adultery, forbidding women from showing their skin or their hair, and forbidding music and TV. Primitive men, who deserve to be beaten.

For our 3000 dead, let there be 100,000 or 1 million innocents dead -- their dead -- and even then our thirst for revenge will not be slaked.

This is why we continue a war in Iraq and kill innocents based on a lie.

This is why we do not ask for the heads of the men who gave the orders for torturing or killing muslim men. It is a war on all fronts.

This is why we demand that all Moslem people, whether they had anything to do with this attack against us, keep apologizing to us, and keep apologizing to us for what 500, maybe 5000 moslem men did.

Unfortunately, none of our words can actually convince people. Witness the comments against your words. In the end these words by Frank Rich, Cavett, and you are just a statement about you, designed to state your positions, but these words change no one, affect no one.

I have been absolutely opposed to building a mosque at Ground Zero. Like many, I feel that  it is hallowed ground. However,  in his pursuasive and brilliant editorial, Mr Kristof,  commented on truths far greater in meaning..... which reach beyond the tragedy of September 11th. I am humbled. In this time of fear and doubt a voice such as his is so welcomed.

I'm mostly hearing blatant Islamophobia being expressed here by people who should know better. Obama is for once standing on principle in this matter. He's actually been showing a little backbone lately. Next, how about having a real open trial of Khalid Sheik Mohammed right in New York City, let it be completely open and let KSM have the best defense attorneys we can find - somebody like David Boise. Then let's see the government prove to a jury that KSM was involved. Or would you all prefer to form a lynch mob?

Those who argue against the Islamic center in lower Manhattan are the American Taliban. I include Palin, Limbaugh, and all others who are after money and self inerest by behaving as ignorant demagogues.

Why yes of course we support the Project, you speak for many, we thankyou.
Even the community centre in our neighbourhood, which is long in need of modernization, (it was once a church) brought out the experts in all areas - as volunteers to plan the best ways forward to serve
all those who live here. Clearly that is what it will take....

Where do you get what is cleary inside information on Obama Bin-Laden? Are you perhaps a liberal Democratic left-wing radical Muslim sympathizer? You should check into that concept, because that's the way you come across.

Dewey. Timothy McVeigh was not a Christian. He was a self professed agnostic. There is no moral equivalence here. In fact, there is strong evidence (which was suppressed by the Clinton adminstration) that the FBI had knowledge that McVeigh was in the Philippines immediately prior to his terrorist attack, and that he had contacted Abu Sayif, a terrorist group operating in Mindinao and linked to various Muslim fantatical groups. I repeat, there is NO moral equivalence. I would ask you, would you support the construction of an edifice towering over Martin Luther King's grave, proposed to bring inter-racial "harmony and understanding"  built by the KKK?

So much animosity towards a religion and its people, you would think there would be another kristallnacht. As good as i think we Americans are in heart, i have a gnawing suspicion that pushed to such extremes of thought and actions, we will all eventually have to come to terms with our fears and emotions. As a nation post WWI, Germany came to terms with theirs and elected someone who personified this "coming of terms" with the problem. Come November, i am wondering who my fellow Americans will elect.

I am highly impressed by Nicholas Kristof’s biography and his knowledgeable and courageous positions on Iraq and other issues. Having read his op-ed piece on the WTC mosque/center carefully several times, I just realized why I don’t classify myself as a party line “Liberal” or Republican. And here’s why:

Many independent and open-minded people of all stripes, not just Republicans, at least question the timing and wisdom of developing an Islamic center/mosque near the WTC. Furthermore, I know hardly anything about the background of Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf and the development organization. Therefore I refuse to take Kristof's word alone on this, and neither should he. He's not addressed this issue sufficiently. That's why we vet the individual and organization(s) involved in this development, especially after the greatest atrocities since Pearl Harbor were committed here and around the world by Islamic terrorists, including Al Qaeda. That's why we have a CIA, FBI, etc. -- and we have learned that they leave much to be desired as Texas visibly demonstrated.

Is Kristof saying that no terrorist cells exist in NYC, especially after two bombings of the WTC? Maybe he needs to focus more attention stateside.

Mr. Kristof even concedes that "Sure, the Islamic world is disproportionately turbulent, and mullahs sometimes cite the Koran to incite murder." Is not the bombing of the WTC and subsequent connected loss of life, blood and treasure -- American and others -- here and in Iraq/Afghanistan/Pakistan enough to warrant a thorough investigation without stopping the development process? Should this not have already been done? Where does Mr. Kristof stand here?

And how does one separate religion from culture, be it Muslim, Christian, Judaism, Atheism or other? And how many "cultures" are part of this organization and project? How is it being financed?

And why has Mr. Kristof remained silent on the statements of President Obama, Majority Leader Harry Reid and Speaker Pelosi?

I remain unconvinced that moving forward without adequate safeguards is wise until or unless we do our homework -- and do it well.
Yes and What about Howard Dean and Harry Reid and 66% of the the American public

Nicholas: I love your columns. You repeatedly put your (and your family's) life where your opinions are and for that reason alone, your views count with me. Unfortunately, I have to disagree with your logic on the reasons to build the Ground Zero mosque.

Because Bin Laden and co are rooting against the Ground Zero mosque being built, it doesn't mean that building the mosque is a good idea. We have already been fooled by this line of reasoning ("spiting you enemy is a good thing") many times over. (We thought) Bil Laden loved Saddam, so we took Saddam out - for what purpose? Now, we believe Bin Laden wants to undermine the Pakistani government, so we support that feckless group and their chameleon armed forces with no expectation of performance or reciprocity. These are tactically brilliant moves and colossal strategic blunders.

Your other arguments are more cogent and relevant - I agree that the Ground Zero Imam is probably a good man; I agree that every religion has been used by unscrupulous politicians for sectarian purposes and so it is wrong to blame the "moderate" observers of that religion. But these arguments do NOT support your conclusion - that building the Ground Zero mosque will resonate as a statement about US support for Islam. What it will resonate as is an abdication by American citizens of their personal responsibility in rejecting violent political Islam - the kind that destroyed the Twin Towers, NO the kind that the Imam represents. If you find my argument hard to follow think of it his way: by your line of reasoning, the Jews who were being burned by the Christians should have agreed to a church in Jerusalem, in honor of the "good" Christians who were NOT the ones that actually burnt the Jews.

I agree that national Republican leaders have not helped by politicizing this issue; but I then expect you to also criticize the President for wading into this issue. Quite honestly, both sides are being pathetic in the way they are using 9/11 for their own political ends.

In the end, I make my decision based on two sets of people: one set is the families of the 9/11 victims, many of whom have said they oppose this mosque and the other, the Imam and his wife and their noble intentions. And in this contest, the question is: if the Twin Towers were NOT destroyed, would anyone have a problem with this mosque being built? The answer is NO. So by building this mosque, we are in effect signing off that we have accepted the Twin Towers bombing as a fait accompli in our psyche and that the victims and their families are no longer part of the equation. I refuse to do that.
